 - 1 - I. THE TRANSPORT SECTOR A. Economic Growth and Impact 1.1 Vietnam is located in mainland Southeast Asia, stretching over 1,600 km from the Chinese border in the north to the Gulf of Thailand in the south. The country's land area is approximately 330,000 km2 and the population now exceeds 70 million. The main sector of economic activity is agriculture, with over 80% of households engaged in that sector alone. Per capita income is estimated at US$250 per year (1995), one of the lowest in the world. However, in 1989, Vietnam introduced an ambitious economic reform program (Doi Moi) and is committed to make the transition to a market economy. The implementation of Doi Moi policies includes liberalization, decentralization, expansion of international relations and strong emphasis on the industrial sector. The result is an actual economic growth rate exceeding expectations: an average of 6.5 percent from 1990 to 1992, 8.1 percent in 1993, 9.0 percent in 1994 and 9.5 percent in 1995. Construction was the fastest growing sector in 1994 with 19%, followed by industry at 14% and services (which continued to expand rapidly) at 10%. Agricultural value added increased 4%. B. The Transport System 1.2 To support its rapid economic growth, Vietnam needs a strong transport sector, both in terms of quantity and quality. However, the actual transport infrastructure (road, rail, river, maritime, air and pipeline) is dilapidated and unreliable and the transport fleet is obsolete. Road is by far the most widely used transport mode, both for freight and passengers. The road network consists of 106,000 km of roads, 10% of which are paved. In the vicinity of large urban areas such as Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh City (HCMC) and Haiphong, the main highways will soon become inadequate to handle the rapidly increasing traffic flows. Large flows of bicycles and the presence of pedestrians on the roads reduce vehicle speeds and are a frequent cause of accidents. Road foundations and surfaces, mostly in the north, have not been designed for heavy trucks and have suffered substantial damage. A significant proportion of roads become impassable after heavy rains; a large number of bridges require rehabilitation or replacement; and almost all ferries need upgrading. Road construction, maintenance techniques and equipment require modernization. 1.3 The rail network consists of six lines in operation and two branch lines, totaling 2,528 km. The network condition is considered unsatisfactory. It is subject to flooding on several sections and different gauges create operational problems between some provinces. Most bridges and tunnels are seriously deteriorated and operating speed is limited on 30% of the total length. Approximately one third of Vietnam's locomotive fleet consists of obsolete steam engines and there is a serious capacity shortage for repairing and maintaining the diesel fleet. Passenger coaches and freight wagons are improperly maintained and in poor condition. Government has obtained funds from Japan (OECF) to rehabilitate major tunnels and bridges in the rail network, so as to improve operational speeds. As in many other countries, the railway's poor physical and operating condition is
 -2 - compounded by its loss of comparative advantage vis-a-vis road transport. Thus, it is estimated that the railway is about four times larger than required for the volume of traffic it is likely to capture and retain in the long run. 1.4 Vietnam has a large inland waterway network suitable for year-round transportation, totaling approximately 11,000 km. The capacity of the inland waterway network is sufficient to cope with the current demand but the fleet condition and operation methods are in need of modernization and dredging is backlogged. The national sea- going fleet is relatively small and consists of small, old ships, not adapted to market requirements. The state-owned shipping companies are no longer subsidized which has forced them to seek private and foreign partners. Several seaports are in operation, some for general cargo and some dedicated to petroleum and coal. Most port equipment is old, operations are inefficient and there is inadequate equipment to handle containers. The two ports at Haiphong and Ho Chi Minh City (HCMC) are being modernized with assistance from the donor community. 1.5 The air transport system also needs selective rehabilitation and upgrading, especially the terminal facilities and air traffic control equipment at the international airports of Hanoi and HCMC. Vietnam Airline's carrying capacity is inadequate; its operational and maintenance techniques need upgrading and it needs to purchase some new aircraft. 1.6 Looking to the future, it can be concluded that continued rapid economic growth, a more diversified economic base and high growth rates in foreign trade would rapidly expand freight traffic, as experienced in Thailand, Malaysia and China. Likewise, with rising personal incomes and mobility, the demand for high quality short and long- distance passenger transport will increase substantially. A Bank Transport Sector Report (TSR)I estimated that total freight traffic would likely increase at annual rates between 7% and 11% for the remainder of the decade (with similar growth rates for passenger transport), although with wide variations for each transport mode. Road freight traffic would grow rapidly (between 9% and 15% p.a.), rail traffic most slowly (between 2% and 4% p.a.) and inland waterway traffic between 4% and 6% p.a. Passenger transport by air is projected to grow most rapidly between 10% and 25% p.a., followed by road passenger transport (between 10% and 17% p.a.). By contrast, inland waterways and rail passenger transport are expected to grow much below average, between 2% and 5% p.a. C. Transport Reforms 1.7 In line with Vietnam's economic reform program a number of important reforms have been undertaken in the transport sector. Notably the Government has: I Vietnam: Transport Sector; Serving an Economy in Transition. August 8, 1994, Report No. 12778-VN.
 - 3 - * eliminated allocation of cargo to specific modes; * abolished prescribed tariffs for road and inland waterway freight transport (except for certain commodities considered of strategic and social importance) and decentralized control over passenger fares which are now determined by the provinces; * replaced controls over entry by less restrictive licensing arrangements and allowed own-account fleets (including the military) to carry for third parties; * opened interurban passenger transport to competition, in stages, and placed urban passenger transport under the control of the people's committees which allocate routes and determine prices; * commercialized state transport enterprises and abolished their most direct operating subsidies; * allowed the establishment of private transport enterprises and private participation in transport infrastructure investment and operation; * reorganized the Ministry of Transport and Communications (MOT) into modal administrations with broad responsibilities under the overall authority of the minister; * initiated first steps towards cost recovery from users of transport infrastructure provided by the state. D. Sector Development Strategy 1.8 In its strategy for development, the Government of Vietnam has accorded a high priority to the transport sector. The Bank's TSR suggests criteria to determine the share appropriate to transport, considering past experience in the region, economic constraints, investment needed to meet development targets, absorptive capacity of the executing agencies and the roles of state and non-state sectors. Based on these factors, the TSR suggests that the public sector allocate 2 - 3% of GDP per year for the next 10- 15 years to restore, modernize and maintain Vietnam's transport system. This would provide approximately US$680 million per year and US$4.1 billion for a six-year period. In addition, the non-state sector would need to spend 1.5 - 2% of GDP per year for vehicles, equipment and other commercial infrastructure. Priority investments will aim at the rehabilitation of key infrastructure, modernization of obsolete equipment and institutional strengthening for management and maintenance. In addition, the TSR recommends market-based policies for the development of the transport sector, such as cost-based user charge policies, sustainable public funding, privately based industrial organization, competitive transport markets and increased management efficiency. 1.9 The TSR recommended further that a number of comprehensive studies should be carried out for roads, inland waterways, ports and urban transport to provide the basis for a coordinated overall sector development plan, taking into account existing and future resource constraints. These studies are now underway, funded by various bilateral and multilateral sources. In addition, a UNDP funded public expenditure review is underway
 - 4 - which will help ensure the sectoral and cross-sectoral coherence of the Government's overall development program. With regard to roads, a study financed under ODA of the UK, has proposed a medium-term investment and maintenance strategy for intercity, national and provincial roads. The study has: (a) defined a 10-year program of road, bridge and ferry improvements and maintenance, (b) estimated budget needs for road maintenance and administration; and (c) proposed an optimum balance between investments and maintenance based on assessed expenditure priorities under alternative multi-period budget scenarios. E. Remaining Challenges 1.10 In the future the above reform initiatives should be deepened in order to eliminate any remaining impediments to efficient markets and transport institutions and much more needs to be done with regard to restoring, modernizing and maintaining the essential transport infrastructure. In particular, the Government will need to carry out (with donor support where appropriate) the following agenda over the next decade: * capital expenditure for public transport infrastructure and facilities should be increased and maintained at a level of about 2-3% of GDP in real terms; * the budget allocation for recurrent expenditure (operating and maintenance expenses) should be increased by a factor of two from 1995 levels (adjusted yearly for inflation) and modern maintenance management techniques should be introduced; * investment planning and project selection should be coordinated between the various levels of government and based on rational selection criteria; L the role of the Government as owner and operator of conmmercially viable transport services (e.g. trucking, shipping, port services) should gradually be reduced, leaving these operations to the private sector; * remaining restrictions on entry, competition and other regulations governing transport markets (including subsidies) should gradually be eliminated and replaced with a regulatory framework and institutions that ensure fair competition, appropriate quality standards for the transport industry, safety and the efficient use of transport infrastructure and other assets; * realign prices for commercial public services and user charges for the provision of infrastructure so that they fully reflect the economic costs of their use; * continue the strengthening of transport institutions; * modernize transport training and research, and upgrade manpower skills. F. Lessons Learned from Previous Bank Involvement 1.11 Since lending to Vietnam has been resumed fairly recently, no transport project has yet been completed. The first transport project (Highway Rehabilitation Project;
 -5- Credit No. 2549-VN ) was approved by the Board in October 1993 and became effective in June 1994. While it is too early for a definitive assessment of the project implementation experience, the problems so far are mainly due to difficulties encountered across all sectors; in particular: the authorities' inexperience with the requirements of international lending agencies; unfamiliarity with IDA procedures; inadequate legislation (e.g. on procurement, resettlement, axle loads); overly centralized decision making often causing delays in prompt action; inadequate counterpart funds; and scarcity of qualified and experienced staff. Various cross-sector and sector initiatives by bilateral and international donors such as EDI-training courses, assistance with drafting legislation on procurement, resettlement and other matters, economic and sector work, as well as reforms being undertaken by the Government itself, are underway to resolve these general problems. The necessary changes require time and it is clear that it will take some time to build up Vietnam's project absorption capacity. Therefore, substantial outside assistance will be needed for the interim period. 1.12 Difficulties with the implementation of the Highway Rehabilitation Project have occurred due to slow, multi-layered and centralized decision making process. The project management unit (PMU 1) is under-budgeted as well as understaffed, and it is still short of the full range of skills required for the efficient and effective processing of the Project. In addition, implementation has been slow due to earlier differences between the Government and IDA on the resettlement policies related to project affected persons, coordination difficulties between different levels of government and the inexperience of local staff charged with the implementation of the resettlement action plan. However, prior to appraisal, these resettlement issues were resolved and the project is implementing smoothly. As resettlement activities under the ongoing project approach the final stages, increasing competency of PMU1 staff and stronger commitment by Government to mutually agreed goals and objectives can be noted in the way resettlement activities are being carried out. Independent monitoring has shown that reorganized PAPs are satisfied with their entitlements and have already restored their income and living standards. Finally, there is some reluctance on the part of government authorities to use Credit funds earmarked for technical assistance designed to address some of the sector wide problems mentioned above. A team of consultants, financed by the proceeds of the Credit, has only recently started its assistance to PMU I and it is expected that the "teething problems" of the unit's functioning will gradually be eliminated. The Government is also moving to resolve the resettlement, budget and staffing issues. Budgetary concerns on the cost of resettlement led to the adoption of a non-cash alternative for creation of new assets which is now being offered to affected people. IDA is continuing its discussions with Government to unblock technical assistance funds available under the Credit for training, studies and other purposes.

Vietnam's public road network consists of about 106,000 km of roads classified as national roads (12,462 km), provincial roads (16,054 km), district roads (21,928 km), viilage roads (46,910 km), urban roads (3,211 km) and special roads (5,451 km). The national and provincial roads, which together carry the bulk of the road traffic in the country, comprise 30% of the total network and of which only 14% is paved. (Table 2.1). Average road density is rather low at 0.32 km/sq km of land area and 1.6 km/1000 inhabitants. Density in the two main deltas is considerably higher, while the lowest densities occur in the highlands along the borders with Lao P.D.R. and China. Some mountainous areas are still inaccessible by road. It is estimated there were about 333,000 motor vehicles registered in Vietnam in 1995 (excluding about 2.9 million motorcycles, 24,000 three- wheelers, and military vehicles). Buses and trucks accounted for 56,600 (17%) and 119,700 (36%) respectively and passenger cars for 156,300 (Table 2.3).3 Vehicle density is low at 4.6 motor vehicles/1,000 inhabitants but typical for a country at Vietnam's level of development. While the number of passenger cars is low, two-wheeled vehicles (both bicycles and motor cycles) are extensively used for passenger travel and for carrying small amounts of cargo. This is especially true in the cities, but also on interurban roads. In the north, motorcycles account for about a third of two-wheeled traffic, while in the Mekong Delta, they account for about two thirds. The little historical data available show the motorized vehicle fleet growing very slowly between 1988 and 1990 when the average annual increase was about 3.5%, roughly in line with GDP growth. Average daily traffic (ADT) on the road network varies considerably between and within regions, from negligible in the outlying highlands to about 21,000 four-wheel vehicles per day around HCMC (1994/95). The highest volumes occur on the approach roads to HCMC and Hanoi where road capacity problems are already apparent. Compounding the capacity problem is the very high number of slow moving motorcycles, bicycles (up to 39,000 per day near the largest cities) and animal-drawn carts. Special attention needs to be given to this slow moving traffic in the design of capacity-increasing measures. In addition, major roads are regularly used as drying grounds for agricultural produce and vendors of produce and services encroach on the shoulders and pavement in many areas - significantly reducing capacity and causing traffic hazards. The road designs for the proposed project take into account these factors and provide hard shoulders for separation of bicycle traffic, make adequate provision for pedestrian movement and crossings and provide specifically constructed roadside drying areas for agricultural products. B. Road Transport Industry 2.6 Structure. Of the approximately 120,000 trucks in Vietnam about 73% belong to cooperatives, joint ventures or the Government -- either the Ministry of Transport (MOT), which operates commercial haulage fleets in the north, or other ministries (including the military), which usually carry goods on "own account," supplemented, sometimes, with commercial haulage. The private sector accounts for 27% of all trucks and 15% of capacity. Almost all private operators have only one vehicle. Similarly about a third of the bus fleet is owned and operated by the private sector while the remaining two-thirds is either state owned or owned by cooperatives and joint ventures. 2.7 As funds for new vehicles are scarce, the truck and bus fleets are aging; almost one third of the truck fleet and some 44% of the bus fleet is estimated to be over 10 years old. Recently some used buses were acquired for city transport with French assistance. 2.8 Prices. Road freight transport remains the most expensive transport mode. The schedule of freight tariffs established in 1993 ranges from 333 Dong/t-km for river
 - 9 - transport to 782 D/t-km by truck and 75 D/t-km by coastal shipping. However, these tariffs calculated by TESI on the basis of vehicle operating costs, are only indicative and mainly applied by state owned enterprises. In principle, the consignor is free to negotiate the rates with the transport operator. 2.9 Passenger fares are normally subject to provincial control, but enforcement is poor, particularly for intermediate journeys. Passenger boardings at bus stations are normally charged the official rate (110, 100 and 80 Dong per passenger/km for north, center and south, respectively, in 1994); otherwise, fares tend to become a matter of negotiation between passengers and vehicle crews. Minibuses and shared taxis are entitled to collect higher fares than big buses, reflecting shorter waiting times and quicker journeys. 2.10 Performance. Trucks are heavily loaded and overloading by 25%-50% for light and medium goods vehicles is common. Trucks cover an estimated average of about 42,000 km/year at an average speed of 30 km/hour and an average loaded/empty ratio of about 59%. There are virtually no major constraints on vehicle availability, since owners have an incentive to keep vehicles on the road. Spares can normally be obtained and workshops, although not well equipped, are able to undertake most repairs. However, due to the age and general condition of the fleet, breakdowns are frequent and down- times are long, causing low utilization rates and requiring a significantly higher number of vehicles than in many other countries. 2.11 Buses outside the urban areas are well loaded with average occupancy of about 80% of seating capacity. Average annual utilization in 1994 was estimated at about 57,000 km/year. Availability is low, typically about 60%-65%. Private operators are licensed by route, but this is not strictly enforced. In the south, they are involved in local services and long distance transport. Provincial transport enterprises are required to serve all main routes. C. Institutional Framework 2.12 Ministry of Transport. At the national level, the Ministry of Transport and Communications (MOT) is responsible for constructing, maintaining and operating highways, railways, inland waterways and ports (except for a few specialized ports such as those dealing with coal and petroleum). Its basic structure and functions are presented in Chart 1. MOT has been divided into two main groups: One set of departments is categorized as "non-productive" and the other set is categorized as "productive." The former set includes functional departments such as those responsible for planning, investment, finance, etc.; individual and separate modal administrations (or departments) responsible for highways, railways, waterways and ports; institutions which act as advisors and also the research and design arm of the Ministry, which includes the research Institute for Transportation, Science and Technology, the Transport Development Strategy
 - 10- Institute (TDSI, formerly known as TESI), the Transport Engineering Design Incorporated (TEDI), as well as a number of vocational schools. The second set of departments includes eight construction corporations responsible for large works, including major repairs and capital construction. These construction corporations fall directly under the responsibility of the Minister. The division into specific groupings is relatively new (1992) and although the functions of the various departments appear to be clear, the lines of responsibility between and among them remain less so. For example, under the new organization, there are five distinctly separate Vice-Ministers responsible for economic matters, capital construction, transportation, science and technology and southern Vietnam, each of which has cross-departmental responsibilities. However, as the structures mature and elements are fine-tuned, some of the anomalies are expected to disappear. In addition, MOT also controls the state truck, barge and shipping companies and port operations, and regulates own-account road and river transport, as well as a few locally licensed enterprises engaged in transport for-hire nationwide. 2.13 Vietnam Road Administration. One of the major changes resulting from MOT's reorganization in recent times is the introduction of modal administrations which will be responsible for each of the major transport modes. Thus, the new Vietnam Road Administration (VRA) was established in January 1993 (Decree 07-CP) as a department directly subordinate to the Minister (Chart 2). VRA has a substantial degree of autonomy and broad powers. It has its own legal status, accounts with the State Treasury and its own budget which is reviewed by MOT and subrnitted to the Prime Minister for approval. Its role and responsibilities encompass the five key road administration tasks, namely: policy formulation, planning, guidance, control and execution.4 2.14 Regional Road Management Units. Reporting to the chief executive of VRA are four Regional Road Management Units (RRMUs 2,4,5,7) of enterprises (first established in 1982 and reorganized in 1992), which are responsible for maintaining 5,275 km of the national road network, and partially responsible for maintaining provincial roads and bridges in the various provinces and urban centers of the regions. In addition, they manage vocational schools concerned with roads, and health clinics for their personnel. RRMU 2 (Hanoi) is responsible for the northern part of the country; RRMU 4 (Vinh) for the northern part of central Vietnam; RRMU 5 (Da Nang) for the southern part of central Vietnam and RRMU 7 (HCMC) for the southern part of the country. The RRMUs are in transition, with each restructuring its respective organizations according to the latest directives from MOT. Each RRMU is responsible for a portion of the national road network in its geographic area, and employs on average about 2,500 people (Table 2.4). Sub-RRMUs are given responsibilities for repair and maintenance of about 150-250 km of road each. Highway Sector Issues 2.24 Road Maintenance. The inadequacy of road maintenance can be traced to two main problems: inadequate planning and minimal funding. Despite recent substantial increases, highway maintenance is still underfunded and execution is substandard, resulting in a loss of productivity, excessive vehicle operating costs and ultimately inefficient use of scarce resources. Deficiencies include technical matters and personnel policies and span the whole spectrum of planning, programming, budgeting, design, execution, supervision and monitoring. Although in theory the agencies concerned with roads should prepare five- year and annual road maintenance plans, the lack of funds make systematic planning meaningless and in practice only one-year plans are prepared. But as Vietnam's experience has amply shown, the planning and funding problems are closely related since road management systems cannot be successful unless enough funding is secured for maintenance. Hence, both issues need to be dealt with simultaneously. 2.25 Until recently, maintenance expenditures for national roads amounted to about 25% - 30% of needs, indicating that most of the network was not maintained. However, the Government is beginning to correct the underfunding problem. For example, in 1995 its allocation for maintenance is estimated to have amounted to about 50% of the funding required for national, provincial and district roads in that year. Furthermore, MOT has
 - 15 - proposed setting up a Road Fund to be financed from the transport fees levied on fuel and from other road user charges. The proposal has been agreed in principle by Government. 2.26 Maintenance of the main trunk roads, such as Highway 1, is intensive but of low quality, which, together with initially weak construction, results in excessive road roughness. Further, the process of allocating and distributing funds is complex and cumbersome. MPI and MOF issue budget guidelines and targets, while the RRMUs and provincial departments submit reports on needs; VRA and the Department of Planning in MOT finalize the maintenance budget for national roads, comment on the one for provincial roads, and secure MOF approvals. The release of funds, once these are allocated, is often delayed, causing difficulties in execution. However, since 1992, a system of advance disbursement has been introduced with some success. 2.27 Execution of maintenance is largely by force account and highly labor intensive. The quality of work can be improved through provision of good standards and specifications for all maintenance activities. Also, equipment is mostly old, in poor condition and inappropriate and there is inadequate supervision and monitoring. Several measures to improve rcutine maintenance are being provided under the on-going first highway project. These include technical assistance to the RRMUs to improve the planning, programming, budgeting, designing and execution of maintenance operations; provision of equipment; and training of personnel. There is further need for modernizing the equipment stock and introducing competitive contracting methods for periodic maintenance and training of road agencies and domestic contractors in contract administration, management and supervision (para 3.8). 2.28 Regulations. Various studies commissioned by the Government have identified inadequate regulation of heavy vehicles as a major problem because virtually all the pavement wear and structural damage of roads is caused by the overloading of heavy vehicles. Rules/regulations on vehicle weight and dimensions are outdated and inadequate. The limits are overly restrictive, although the reverse tends to be true of limits and rules relating to vehicle safety features and conditions. No limits exist for axle loads, but those for gross vehicle weight are only 13 tons and 16 tons for semi-trailers; this indicates a limit of eight tons for a single axle, while a limit of 10 tons would be more reasonable. The vehicle height limit of 3.5 meters precludes the legal movement of ISO containers on a conventional chassis. However, containers appear to move freely on roads near the major ports, probably on the basis of exemptions granted by MOT. The overall problem is compounded by ambiguities and omissions in the assignment of responsibilities for enforcement. Under an ADB financed project, consultants are reviewing the institutional and legal arrangements for managing the road sector including development of appropriate traffic regulations. 2.29 Road User Charges. After the recent introduction of the transport fee on fuel used in road transport it appears that the level of road user charges is now adequate. However, the remaining distortions which should be eliminated concern the structure of road user charges. Various studies (TSR; Scott Wilson Kirkpatrick; N.D. Lea) have
 - 16 - concluded that diesel fuel and heavy vehicles are taxed rather low and that this amounts to an indirect subsidy to diesel powered heavy vehicles and provides no fiscal incentive to users of heavy vehicles to utilize vehicles with sufficient axles that (in conjunction with axle load limits) would help reduce substantially the wear and tear on the roads and thus preserve the Government's investment. The studies recommended to raise the fuel tax on diesel vehicles to the level of the gasoline tax and, in addition, to introduce specific charges designed to reflect the equivalent standard axles (ESAs) of heavy vehicles and thus the damage they inflict on pavements. MOT is currently reviewing these recommendations. With regard to diesel taxes the Government has recently introduced some small (but still insufficient) modifications in the context of IDA's first structural adjustment credit. This issue should be further reviewed in IDA's macro-economic dialogue with the Government with a view to reduce the gap even more. As regards axle load charges it would be appropriate for MOT to consider the consultants' recommendations. 2.30 Resettlement. The Government appears to recognize that a new and comprehensive policy aligned to the requirements of the multilateral agencies needs to be established and has obtained from the Bank (through an IDF grant) assistance to develop its national policy on resettlement. However, preparing and reaching agreement with Government on a comprehensive policy and the associated implementation procedures, acceptable to IDA for all sectors, could take about two years. Therefore, in the interim, resolution of the present differences need to be on the basis of specifically prepared Resettlement Action Plans (RAPs) satisfactory to IDA, including project specific resettlement policies, guidelines for implementation and Government's commitment to compensate the already affected persons on the project road sections. 2.31 Traffic Safety. Since 1990, traffic accidents and fatalities in Vietnam have doubled and injuries tripled. According to the statistics collected by the Traffic Police, 13,118 accidents claimed 4,533 lives and 13,586 injuries on roads in 1994. The fatality rate - number of fatalities per 10,000 registered vehicles - is amounting to about 13.0. Notwithstanding the differences in composition of vehicle fleets, this rate is the highest among the neighboring countries (e.g. Thailand 12.1, Malaysia 8.0, and Philippines 9.0), and around six times higher than rates in the developed countries (Japan 1.8, Australia 2.3, Norway 2.0, and Sweden 2.0). The numbers are, however, thought to be much higher since accident data are neither accurate nor complete in Vietnam. Under-reporting is acknowledged by the Traffic Police to be very severe. 2.32 The factors responsible for the high accident rate include inappropriate design of some road segments, poor vehicle condition, unsafe driver behavior, but most importantly the broad mix of vehicles on roads. Although the 1994 Traffic Police Report determined improper driving is the greatest cause for accidents, which is said to be because of the inadequate driver education, scarce driving discipline and use of alcohol, broad mix of vehicles on roads is actually creating the dangerous exposure to accidents.

About 50% of all accidents occurred on the national highways, 30% on urban roads and 20% on rural roads. Broad mix of vehicles is most serious on the national highways where trucks and buses run with high speeds along with the non- motorized vehicles that are moving slowly on the same lanes. 2.33 The Government has taken significant actions to address these problems. However, since the budget has been very limited and been used only to implement publicity and education programs, no physical improvement of roads has been included in the safety plan. At present the NTSC has no formal technical support organization although such support is needed. Introduction 4.1 The project continues the reconstruction and rehabilitation of Highway 1, started under IDA's First Highway Project and upon completion it, together with corresponding projects financed by Japan and ADB will provide the only efficient transport link between the economic growth areas of the north, center and the south. Moreover, the rehabilitation of Highway I will significantly reduce the Central Coastal Provinces' relative geographical isolation, improve their access to national and international markets and thus eliminate a major obstacle to the economic and social development of one of the poorest regions in Vietnam. In addition, the Pilot Periodic Maintenance program will introduce modern road maintenance methods and reduce vehicle operating costs on the 950 km of high priority roads selected throughout the country. B. Methodology 4.2. The proposed Project has been evaluated on a with and without project basis. Without the project the Vinh - Dong Ha section of Highway 1 would continue to deteriorate and vehicle operating costs and road maintenance costs would increase rapidly. Moreover, road accidents would likely be higher and flooding of parts of the road would occur more frequently than with the project. 4.3 Various road rehabilitation options were tested by means of the Bank's Highway Design and Maintenance Model (HDM III) and one was found optimal in terms of economic return, improved road safety and flood protection (Annex 4.1). The option chosen consists of the rehabilitation of the Vinh - Dong Ha section to the specified road standards and includes the reconstruction of two bridges, additional culverts and embankments and bridge raising to eliminate flooding on all sections of the highway, based on a maximum overtopping of 30 cm. This solution means that flooding will be reduced only to extraordinary events occurring on average once in 10 years. 4.4 Construction is assumed to begin at Vinh and Dong Ha simultaneously, progressing from both ends towards the center, which is feasible from the point of view of logistics and which tends to maximize the economic return since the most viable sections would be completed first. It has also been assumed that roughly one third of the highway is completed by the end of 1998, 1999 and 2000 respectively. Thus benefits begin to build up in the period 1998 - 2000 and continue until the end of 2010, the assumed life of the project.
 - 32 - C. Costs and Benefits 4.5 Costs and benefits were calculated in terms of 1995 prices on a resource cost basis, i.e. all transfer payments such as taxes and interest are excluded. The costs of the project consist of the costs of road construction and rehabilitation (including design and supervision) of the Vinh -Dong Ha section of Highway 1; the construction of two major bridges and other works; the costs of resettlement and relocation and the recurrent costs of routine and periodic maintenance. The benefits included in the economic analysis consist of reduced motor vehicle operating costs (the most important benefit); reduced motorcycle operating costs; savings in existing vehicle travel time costs; reduced road maintenance costs and benefits related to improved flood protection. Due to an inadequate data base benefits from increased road safety and the increased road and bridge capacity were iAot quantified. No account was taken either of the potential for generated traffic. Furthermore, the benefits of replacing the ferry services at Quan Hau with a bridge were not taken into account because of unavailability of reliable data. The costs of the bridge were therefore treated as part of the costs of road improvement. 4.6 The project component "periodic maintenance of priority road sections", comprising about 33 % of total project costs, has been selected on the basis of the technical and economic feasibility of each selected section, taking into account as well their pilot character as demonstration projects for the introduction of new road maintenance management techniques, and hence its geographic location. The total costs of this component include periodic maintenance on the selected roads, supervision, maintenance equipment for VRA and the RRMUs and physical contingencies. Reduced vehicle operating costs for four-wheel vehicles, based on the HDM calculations, are the main econornic benefits of the maintenance program. Reduced operating costs of motorbikes (which are estimated to constitute about 20% of total benefits on the Vinh- Dong Ha segment of Highway 1) have not been included in the analysis because traffic counts for these vehicles were not available for the roads included in the maintenance program. 4.7 Other project costs and benefits, such as support to PMU 1, VRA and other agencies, training and studies (4.7 % of total project costs), cannot directly be attributed to the rehabilitation of the Vinh - Dong Ha section of Highway 1 since the entire transport sector will benefit in the form of more efficient institutions and decision making and skilled human resources. Road maintenance in Vietnam consists largely of three activities - routine maintenance (such as vegetation clearing, shoulder and roadside repairs, drainage cleaning, and maintenance of road signs); medium repairs (such as pothole patching, crack resealing, spot regravelling, etc.); and big repairs (such as resealing, overlays, regravelling and minor rehabilitation). 2. Periodic maintenance encompasses the maintenance activities carried out as big repairs. However, due to budget constraints, this level of maintenance has not been accorded the priority it should have over construction or major rehabilitation. The Scot Wilson Study of Investment and Maintenance Strategy for National and Provincial Roads (July 1996), has estimated periodic maintenance funding needs amounting to US$31.9 million per annum on National and US$5.7 million per annum on Provincial roads during 1997-2001. Currently government is allocating little or no funds for programmed periodic maintenance of roads. 3. The objective of this component is to initiate a pilot program for regular planning, programming, budgeting and execution of periodic maintenance of National roads to be undertaken by contracts awarded through national competitive bidding. This component is a logical follow up to the maintenance management strengthening TA financed under the on-going highway rehabilitation project. The component would be supervised by internationally recruited consultants who would also have the responsibility to train staff of VRA and the RRMUs in contract administration and management, including preparation of bid documents. The consultants would also oversee and train domestic contractors in bid preparation, works planning, contract management and quality control. 4. A preliminary list of roads to be considered has been selected on the basis of road condition, traffic level, geographic distribution and estimated cost (Table 1). The list includes sections of Highway No. 1, mostly between Dong Ha and Quan Ngai that are in a reasonably good to fair condition, justifying only minor repairs of the carriageway plus an asphalt concrete overlay (or surface dressing) without widening or re-alignment. Hence there will be no land acquisition or involuntary resettlement of people resulting from such periodic maintenance activities. 5. Due to the geographic distribution of individual sections of roads required to be maintained and the need to use and develop the local construction industry, the contracts would be packaged in lots suitable for national competitive bidding (NCB). Only in the case of contiguous road sections on Highway No. 1, the works would be packaged together in four lots to make it attractive for ICB and domestic contractors.

For these reasons the Government of Vietnam should improve policies, regulations, training, and education. Also, to reduce the risk of accidents and traffic disturbance, the proposed design of the road suggests the creation of paved shoulders along the road for slower traffic; these shoulders will contribute to the separation of slow from fast moving traffic and to the improvement of safety for every road user.  - 55 - Annex 3.7 Page 1 of 4 VIETNAM Second Highway Rehabilitation Project Summary of Resettlement Action Plan Introduction 1. The Ministry of Transport (MOT) has identified a project to rehabilitate Highway No. 1 between Vinh and Dong Ha. This Project (HRP-2) promotes the objectives of the Government of Vietnam (GOV) to improve national road infrastructure and, in particular, the main transportation route, Highway No. 1. 2. The Vinh - Dong Ha section of Highway No. I is located in the coastal plain of central Vietnam. The road crosses mostly rural areas dominated by rice production. 3. The Project consists of the rehabilitation of 292 km of road to a class Im road according to Vietnamese standard (TCVN 40-54-85) in order to allow for safe and efficient road transportation of people and goods. The Project will require the acquisition of land for the widening of the road and for the development of resettlement sites. Rehabilitation of Highway No. 1 will displace or adversely affect the standard of living of people living in the project corridor. 4. A Resettlement Action Plan (RAP) has been prepared in accordance with the relevant GOV laws and guidelines and the World Bank Operational Directive 4.30 on involuntary resettlement and it gives in greater detail the levels of adverse impact, compensation and rehabilitation policy, and monitoring arrangements (see project files). The main objective of the RAP is to improve, or at least restore, the standard of living and the income of all categories of Project Affected Persons (PAPs) after the implementation of the RAP. Scope 5. The RAP is based on a socioeconomic survey initially conducted in April 1995, and updated in November 1995 following the enforcement of GOV Decree CP/36 on traffic safety; and on a detailed measurement survey (DMS) conducted from June to August 1996 to identify the exact losses of PAPs. The RAP for HRP-2 utilized the experiences from the first Highway rehabilitation project (HRP- 1) on the road section Hanoi-Vinh and Ho Chi Minh City-Can Tho and from a project funded by the Asian Development Bank (ADB-1) between Nha Trang and Ho Chi Minh City. 6. A total of 8,487 households (37,764 persons) will be affected by the project. Of these, 2,327 households (11,056 persons) will suffer impacts due to reorganization or relocation of structures, 1,571 households (6,713 persons) will be affected by acquisition of residential land and 4,589 households (19,995 persons) will be affected by agricultural and forestry land acquisition.

Based on the socioeconomic surveys and on the DMS, the categories of impacts identified, policies for compensation, relocation and/or rehabilitation have been established, even for people affected only through land acquisition. Compensation will be paid at replacement cost for affected assets without depreciation. Persons affected by house acquisition will be: a) reorganized on the same site, but behind the right-of-way (ROW) if they have sufficient remaining area or b) relocated (self relocation, relocation to individual or group resettlement site). In both cases, permanent land use rights certificate would be issued to the PAPs. Persons affected by land acquisition will be compensated for land in cash at replacement cost if they are only marginally affected, or with land-for-land compensation or cash at PAPs option if they are severely affected. An action plan for rehabilitating and compensating the PAPs affected by clearance under Decree 36/CP is included in the RAP. Implementation Arrangements 8. The RAP will be implemented through a strategy of creation of assets and community development in suitable locations. It will be implemented by the Peoples' Committees at the provincial, district and commune levels under the general direction of the Highway No. 1 Project Management Unit (PMU 1). 9. Activities required to implement the RAP satisfactorily are: - Determining Detailed Compensation Rates Provinces will establish unit rates for compensation based on replacement cost and affected area rather than useable area of structures. PMU 1 and the monitoring organization will review the rates and advise revisions where necessary. An inter- ministerial commission will be set up at the national level, if necessary to resolve outstanding differences in provisional unit rates which cannot be resolved at the provincial level. Resettlement Sites After the selection of resettlement sites, preparation of layouts and site development plans will be undertaken. Contracts for site development will then be awarded. Some parameters, not included in HDM-lI (e.g. motorcycle operating costs), were estimated separately and incorporated as exogenous data. This summary of the economic evaluation outlines the methodology used in forecasting traffic, determining economic costs and benefits, selecting the optimal rehabilitation/reconstruction solution from a number of alternatives and testing the sensitivity of the chosen solution to changes in key cost and benefit variables. 1. Costs and Benefits 2.1 Costs The costs taken into account in the evaluation are the economic costs of the various rehabilitation options considered, i.e. taxes, interest and other transfer payments are excluded. No attempt was made to estimate shadow prices of inputs (such as labor) since factor and product markets in Viet Nam are reasonably undistorted and international inputs are provided on the basis of international competitive bidding. On this basis the cost categories taken into account are construction costs, including engineering, procurement and construction management costs; maintenance costs, including administration (O&M); resettlement/relocation costs and vehicle operating costs. Construction cost estimates are based on information provided by local and international contractors and from the analysis of recent bids for similar projects in Viet Nam and other Asian countries. For items such as asphaltic concrete, common excavation etc., average unit prices of the five lowest bids received for such items for the first IDA highway project were used. Therefore, the construction cost estimates are considered realistic and reflect current road construction costs in Viet Nam. Unit road maintenance costs after construction are based on the assumption that improved methods and standards are used. Maintenance costs for the status quo and each improvement option were estimated by the HDM-III model. Resettlement and relocation costs are based on actual compensation paid in two similar road projects. Vehicle operating costs were calculated by the VOC component of the HDM-IlI model and motorcycle operating costs were calculated on the basis of technical, operating and cost characteristics relevant for Viet Nam. 2.2 Economic Benefits The main quantified economic benefits for the various rehabilitation options analysed are savings in existing vehicle operating costs (VOC); savings in motorcycle r)perating costs (MOC); savings in vehicle travel time costs; reduced road maintenance costs and be.nefits from flood protection. In addition, a residual value of US$5 mill. at the end of the project's life was estimated by the HDM-III model and included as a benefit. Other economic benefits such as benefits from increased safety, increased road capacity or generated traffic due to the improved quality of the road were not quantified because of lack of reliable information. The various categories of benefits have been calculated as follows. Savings in VOC were calculated by the HDM-III model as the difference between the status quo and the various rehabilitation options considered. Savings in motorcycle operating costs could not be entered directly into the HDM-III model. These benefits were estimated by determining existing MOC and assuming that percentage reductions in unit MOC are the same as for passenger cars calculated by the HDM-III model. Annual benefit were calculated by multiplying unit MOC by the estimated number of annual motorcycle vehicle kilometers. The results thus obtained were compared with results obtained by other methods and all methods produced savings of approximately one US-cent per motorcycle kilometer. Savings in vehicle travel time costs are automatically calculated by the HDM-Ill model through a comparison of the status quo with the various rehabilitation options. The same procedure applies to savings in road maintenance costs. Benefits from flood protection have been estimated on the basis of the economic value of passenger time or crew wages and an opportunity cost calculated for vehicles and cargo carried as well as a reduction in the cost of rescue activities.

doc.abstracts: The broader developmental goal of the Second Highway Rehabilitation Project is to raise overall economic efficiency and support the country's economic and social development through an improved transport infrastructure. The specific project objectives are: to reduce transport costs through improved national road infrastructure, particularly, Highway No. 1; to enhance the efficiency by road sector institutions in periodic maintenance of the national road network; to reduce vehicle overloading and improve traffic safety; and to enhance the Ministry of Transport and Communications' institutional capacity in environmental impact assessment and monitoring. The project will comprise the following components: (1) Road maintenance and rehabilitation -this includes reconstructing the Vinh-Dong Ha section of National Highway No. 1, reconstructing two major bridges at Chanh Hoa and Quan Hau; acquiring land, resettling and rehabilitating project-affected people, and providing supervision consultant services; (2) Periodic maintenance of selected priority national roads -this aims at systematic, periodic maintenance of national highways by contract, and implementation of the new road maintenance management system being developed under the on-going first highway rehabilitation project; (3) Improvement of hazardous road sections -selected critical sections of national highways will be improved based on the Vietnam Road Safety Improvement Study made under the first highway rehabilitation project, and will include measures to improve traffic safety like providing adequate road furniture, signs, and traffic management facilities; (4) Support to the Project Management Unit for Highway No. 1 (PMU1) -this will further enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of PMU1 to manage highway projects by purchasing vehicles and office equipment, construct an operating center, and give technical support for project implementation, monitoring and evaluation functions, operation cost, staff training, and support for environmental impact assessment; (5) Support to the Vietnam Road Administration (VRA) and the Regional Road Management Unions (RRMU) -this will enhance institutional capacity by providing additional maintenance equipment for RRMUs and axle load weighing stations and equipment for VRA; (6) Training -this will train the trainers for the transport sector training system, strengthen local institutions, and enhance the skills of highway sector manpower; (7) Detailed design and engineering studies -this includes the design and engineering study of two road sections and detailed design and preparation of bid documents for future periodic maintenance components.
